editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

keywords.term: English drama -- 17th century -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: Ram-alley: or merrie-trickes. A comedy divers times heretofore acted by the children of the King's revels.
At London printed by G. eld, for Robert Wilson, and are to be sold at his shop in Holborn, at the new gate of Gray's inn. 1611.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: Homebred mirth our muse doth sing,
The satyr's tooth and waspish sting,
Which most do hurt when least suspected,
By this play are not affected;
But if conceit with quick-turned scenes,
Observing all those ancient streams,
Which from the horsefoot fount do flow,
As time, place, person, and to show,
Things never done with that true life,
That thoughts and wits shall stand at strife,
Whether the things now shown be true,
Or whether we ourselves now do
The things we but present: if these
Free from the loathsome stage disease,
(So overworn, so tired and stale,
Not satiring but to rail,)
May win your favours, and inherit
But calm acceptance for his merit:
A vows by paper, pen and ink,
And by the learned sister's drink,
To spend his time, his lamps, his oil,
And never cease his brain to toil,
Till from the silent hours of night,
He doth produce for your delight,
Conceits so new, so harmless free,
That Puritans themselves may see
A play, yet not in public preach,
That players such lewd doctrine teach
That their pure joints do quake and tremble,
When they do see a man resemble
The picture of a villain: this
As he a friend to muses is,
To you by me 'a gives his word,
Is all his play doth now afford.

div.head: Ram-alley.
Actus 1. Scaena 1,
div.stage: Enter Constantia sola, with a letter in her hand.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: In this disguise, (Ere scarce my mourning robes)
Could have a general note, I have forsook,
My shape, my mother ▪ and those rich demeans,
Of which I am sole heir, and now resolve,
In this disguise of page to follow him,
Whose love first caused me to assume this shape.
Lord how my feminine blood stirs at the sight
Of these same breeches, methinks this codpiece
Should betray me: well, I will try the worst,
Hither they say he usually doth come,
Whom I so much affect, what makes he here
In the skirts of Holborn, so near the field,
And at a garden house, 'a has some punk
Upon my life: no more here he comes.
God save you sir: your name unless I err,
Is master Thomas Boutcher.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: 'Tis sweet boy. Con. delivers the letter.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I have a letter for you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The inside sir will tell you: I shall seeHe reads it.
What love he bears me now.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Thou'rt welcome boy.
How does the fair Constantia Somerfield,
My noble mistress.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: She gives thee here good words, and for her sake,
Thou shalt not want a master, be mine for ever.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I thank you sir: now shall I see the punk.He knocks

div.stage: Enter William Small-shank.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.p: Who knocks so fast? I thought 'twas you, what news.

sp.speaker: Bout.
sp.p: You know my business well, I sing one song.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: Foot, what would you have me do, my land is gone,
My credit of less trust than courtier's words
To men of judgement, and for my debts
I might deserve a knighthood; what's to be done?
The knight my father will not once vouchsafe
to call me son; that little land 'a gave,
Throat the lawyer swallowed at one gob,
For less than half the worth, and for the city
There be so many rascals, and tall yeomen
Would hang upon me for their maintenance,
Should I but peep or step within the gates,
That I am forced only to ease my charge,
To live here in the suburbs: or in the town
To walk in tenebris, I tell you sir,
Your best retired life is an honest punk
In a thatched house with garlic: tell not me,
My punk's my punk, and noble lechery
Sticks by a man, when all his friends forsake him.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: The pox it will, art thou so senseless grown,
So much endeared to thy bestial lust,
That thy original worth should lie extinct
And buried in thy shame? far be such thoughts
From spirits free and noble: begin to live,
Know thyself, and whence thou art derived,
I know that competent state thy father gave,
Cannot be yet consumed.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: 'Tis gone by heaven,
Not a denier is left.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Impossible 'sheart ▪ I have had two suckers,
Able to spend the wealthy Croesus' store.

div.stage: Enter Francis.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Why a lawyer and a whore,
See here comes one, dost think this petticoat,
A perfumed smock, and twice a week a bath,
Can be maintained with half a years revenues,
No by heaven, we annual younger brothers,
Must go to't by wholesale, by wholesale man
These creatures are maintained: her very face
Has cost a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: They keep this whore betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You know sir,
I did enjoy a quiet country life,
Spotless and free, till you corrupted me,
And brought me to the court, I never knew,
What sleeking, glazing, or what pressing meant,
till you preferred me to your aunt the lady,
I knew no ivory teeth, no caps of heir,
No Mercury water, fucas, or perfumes,
To help a lady's breath, until your aunt,
Learned me the common trick.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: The common trick,
Say you, a pox upon such common tricks,
They will undo us all.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: And knowing this
Art thou so wilful blind, still to persist
In ruin and defame.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: What should I do?
I've passed my word to keep this gentlewoman,
Till I can place her to her own content,
And what is a gentleman but his word.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Why let her go to service.

sp.speaker: W s.
sp.l: To service,
Why so she does, she is my laundress,
And by this light, no puny inn a court
But keeps a laundress at his command
To do him service, and shall not I, ha!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, you are his friend (I love him to)
Propound a course which may advantage him,
And you shall find such real worth in me,
That rather then I'll live his hindrance,
I will assume the most penurious state
The city yields, to give me means of life ▪

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks s
sp.l: Why there's it, you hear her what she says,
Would not he be damned that should forsake her,
Says she not well, can you propound a course,
To get my forfeit land, from yonder rogue,
Parcel lawyer, parcel devil, all knave,
Thrate, throat.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Why so, I thought as much ▪
You are like our citizens to men in need,
Which cry 'tis pity, a proper gentleman,
Should want money, yet not an usuring slave,
Will lend him a denier, to help his wants,
Will you lend me forty shillings.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Why godamercy, there's some goodness in thee,
You'll not repent.

sp.speaker: W. S.
sp.l: With that money
I will redeem my forfeit land, and wed
My cockatrice to a man of worship,
to a man of worship by this light.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Thus in Ram-alley lies a fellow, by name
Throat: one that professeth law, but indeed
Has neither law nor conscience, a fellow
That never saw the bar, but when his life
Was called in question for a cozenage,
The rogue is rich, to him go you, tell him
That rich sir John Somerfield.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Is lately dead, and that my hopes stand fair
To get his only daughter. If I speed,
And have but means to steal away the wench,
Tell him I reckon him my chiefest friend,
To entertain us till our nuptial rites
May be accomplished, and could you but procure
My elder brother meet me on the way,
And but associate me unto his house,
'Twere hit i'faith, I'd give my cunning throat
An honest slit for all his tricks in law.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Why this shall be performed, take there's my store,
To friends all things are common.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Then at the court
There are none foes, for all things there are common.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will as carefully perform thy wish,
As if my fortunes lay upon th'attempt.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: When shall I here from you.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Let me alone for the rest, if I gull not
And go beyond my open throated lawyer,
For all his book cases of tricesimo nono
And quadragessimo octavo: let me
Like waiting gentlewomen be ever bound,
To sit upon my heels, and pick rushes,
Will you about this gear.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: Then fare you well, you'll meet me.

div.stage: Exit Bouch: and page.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Adieu: now you pernicious cockatrice,
You see how I must skelder for your good,
I'll bring you where you shall have means to cheat,
If you have grace enough to apprehend it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Believe me love, howe'er some stricter wits,
condemn all women which are prone to love,
And think that if their favour fall on any,
By consequence they must be naught with many,
And hold a false position, that a woman
False to herself, can trusty be to no man,
Yet know I say, howe'er my life hath lost
The fame which my virginity aspired,
I will be true to thee, my deed shall move,
To win from all men pity, if not love.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Tut, I know thee a good rascal, let's in,
And on with all your neat and finest rags.
On with your cloak and safeguard, you arrant drab,
You must cheat without all conscience, filch for thee and me.
Do but thou act what I shall well contrive,
We'll teach my lawyer a new way to thrive. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter mistress Tafata, and Adriana her maid above.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Come loved Adriana here let us sit,
And mark who passes; now for a wager,
What coloured beard comes next by the window?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I think not so,
I think a red, for that is most in fashion,
Lord how scarce is the world of proper men
And gallants; sure we never more shall see
A good leg worn in a long silk stocking,
With a long codpiece, of all fashions
That carried it i'faith, what's he goes by?

div.stage: Enter a citizen.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A snivelling citizen, he is carrying ware,Exit.
Unto some lady's chamber: but who's this?

div.stage: Enter T. Smallshank reading a letter.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: I know him not, 'a looks just like a fool.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: He's very brave a may be a courtier,
What's that 'a reads.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Ah how light 'a treads
For dirting his silk stockings, I'll tell thee what,
A witty woman may with ease distinguish,
All men by their noses, as thus: your nose
Tuscan is lovely, large and broad,
Much like a goose, your valiant generous nose.
A crooked smooth and a great puffing nose,
Your scholar's nose is very fresh and raw
For want of fire in winter, and quickly smells,
His chops of mutton, in his dish of porridge.
Your Puritan nose is very sharp and long,
And much like your widows, and with ease can smell,
An edefying capon some five streets off,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: O mistress a very proper gentleman,

sp.speaker: Tafa.
sp.l: And trust me so it is, I never saw
A man that sooner could captive my thoughts
(Since I writ widow) then this gentleman,
I would a would look up.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I'll laugh so loud
That he may hear me.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: And spoke you with master Small-shank.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'A said a would,
And I believed him, I tell you master
I have done that for many of these gallants
That no man in this town would do but I.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why trust them on their words
But will you hear the news which now supplies,
The city with discourse.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This sir, they say some of our city dames
Were much desirous to see the baboons
Do their newest tricks, went, saw them, came home,
Went to bed, slept, next morning one of them,
Being to shift a smock, sends down her maid,
To warm her one, meanwhile she begins to think
On the baboons tricks, and naked in her bed
Begins to practise some, at last she strove,
To get her right leg over her head; thus:
And by her activity she got it
Cross he shoulder: but not withal her power,
Could she reduce it, at last much struggling
Tumbles quite from the bed upon the flower,
The maid by this returned with the warm smock,
And seeing her mistress thrown on the ground
Trust up like a football, exclaims, calls help,
runs down amazed, swears that her mistress neck
Is broke up comes her husband and neighbours,
And finding her thus trussed, some flatly said
She was bewitch, others she was possessed,
A third said for her pride, the devil had set
Her face where her rump should stand, but at last
Her valiant husband steps me boldly to her,
Helps her; she a shamed; her husband amazed,
The neighbours laughing as none forbear,
She tells them of the fatal accident.
To which one answers, that if her husband
Would leave his trade, and carry his wife about
To do this trick in public, she'd get more gold
Than all the baboons, calves with two tails,
Or motions whatsoever .

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: He will be gone if we neglect to stay him.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: No I have't stand aside ,
Ay me my handkercher Adriana, Fabia.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Run, run I have let my handkercher fall,
Gentleman shall I entreat a courtesy,

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Within my power your beauty shall command.
What courtesy is't.

sp.speaker: Tas.
sp.l: To stoop and take up,
My handkercher.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir most hearty thanks: please you come in
Your welcome shall transcend your expectation.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I accept your courtesy, ha! what's this?
Assailed by fear and hope in a moment.
Boucher this womanish passion fits not men,
Who know the worth of freedom: shall smiles and eyes
With their lascivious glances conquer him
Hath still been lord of his affections?
Shall simpering niceness loadstones but to fools,
Attract a knowing spirit: it shall, it does,
Not Phoebus rising from Aurora's lap,
Spreads his bright rays with more majestic grace
Then came the glances from her quickening eye
And what of this.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: By my troth I know not

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I will not enter: continued flames burn strong,
I yet am free and reason keeps her seat,
Above all fond affections yet is she fair.

div.stage: Enter Adriana.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Sir I bring you thanks for this great courtesy,
And if you please to enter I dare presume,
My mistress will afford you gracious welcome,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: How do men call your mistress.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Her name sir is mistress changeable, late wife
To master Tafata mercer deceased.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: I have heard she is both rich and beautiful,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: In th' eyes of such as love her, judge yourself.
Please you but prick forward and enter,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Now will I fall a board the wating maid,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Fall a board of me, dost take me for a ship,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I and will shoot you betwixt wind and water.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Blurt master gunner your linstocks too short.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Foot how did she know that, dost here sweet heart
Should not the page be doing with the maid,
Whilst the master is busy with the mistress,
Please you prick forwards, thou art a wench
Likely to go the way of all flesh shortly

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: At mine faith, I should breech thee.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: I breech thee, I have breech a taler man,
Than you in my time, come in and welcome.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well I see now a rich well-practised bawd,
May purse more fees in a summer's progress,
Than a well traded lawyer in a whole term,
Pandarism! why't is grown a liberal science
Or a new sect, and the good professors
Will like the brownist frequent gravel pits shortly,
For they use woods and obscure holes already.
Not marry a widow.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: And why?
Belike you think it base and servant-like,
To feed upon reversion, you hold us widows,
But as a pie thrust to the lower end
That hath had many fingers in't before,
and is reserved for gross and hungry stomachs.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: Come in faith you do:
And let me tell you that's but ceremony,
For though the pie be broken up before,
Yet says the proverb, the deeper is the sweeter.
And though a capon's wings and legs be carved,
The flesh left with the rump I hope is sweet.
I tell you sir, I have been wooed, and sued to,
By worthy knights of fair demeans: nay more,
They have been out of debt, yet till this hour,
I neither could endure, to be in love.
Or be beloved, but proffered ware is cheap.
What's lawful that's loathed, and things denied,
Are with more stronger appetite pursued.
I am to yielding.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You mistake my thoughts.
But know thou wonder of this continent,
By one more skilled in unknown fate, then was,
The blind achaean prophet, it was foretold,
A widow should endanger both my life,
My soul, my lands, and reputation,
This checks my thoughts, and cools th'essential fire,
Of sacred love; more ardent in my breast
Then speech can utter.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: A trivial idle jest,
'Tis for a man, of your repute, and note,
To credit fortune-tellers, a petty rogue,
That never saw five shillings, in a heap
Will take upon him to divine men's fate,
Yet never knows himself, shall die a beggar,
Or be hanged up for pilfering tablecloths,
Shirts and smocks, hanged out to dry on hedges,
'Tis merely base, to trust them, or if there be,
A man in whom the Delphic, God hath breathed,
His true divining fire, that can foretell,
The fixed decree of fate, he likewise knows,
What is within the everlasting book,
Of destiny decreed cannot by wit,
Or man's invention be dissolved, or shunned,
Then give thy love free scope embrace and kiss,
And to the distaff sisters leave th'event,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: How powerful are their words whom we affect,
small force shall need, to win the strongest fort,
If to his state the captain be perfidious,
I must entreat you licence my depart
For some few hours.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Choose what you will of time,
There lies your way.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Who begins to love, needs not a second hell.

div.stage: Ent. Adr.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I prithee see if he have left the house,
Peep close, see, but be not seen: is a gone.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Nay, keep you close y'ad best.

sp.speaker: Bou,
sp.l: O you much partial gods!
Why gave you men affections, and not a power
To govern them? what I by fate should shun,
I most affect, a widow, a widow.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A ha, he's in i'faith,
You've drawn him now within your purlieus mistress.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Tut I will not love, my rational
And better parts shall conquer blind affections,
Let passion children, or weak women sway,
My love shall to my judgement still obey.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: 'A went his way, and never looked behind him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A little singed or so,
Each thing must have beginning, men must prepare
Before they can come on, and show their loves
In pleasing sort: the man will do in time,
For love good mistress is much like to wax,
The more 'tis rubbed, it sticks the faster too,
Or like a bird in birdlime, or a pitfall,
The more 'a labours, still the deeper in.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Come, thou must help me now, I have a trick
To second this beginning, and in the nick,
To strike it dead i'faith, women must woe,
When men forget what nature leads them too.

div.stage: Enter throat the lawyer from his study books and bags of money on a table, a chair and cushion.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Chaste Phoebe, splende; there's that left yet,
Next to my book, claro micante auro,
I that's the soul of law: that's it, that's it,
For which the buckram bag must trudge all weathers:
Though scarcely filled with one poor replication,
How happy are we that we joy the law,
So freely as we do; not bought and sold,
But clearly given, without all base extorting,
Taking but bare ten angels for a fee,
Or upward: to this renowned estate,
Have I by indirect and cunning means,
Inwoven myself, and now can scratch it out,
Thrust at a bar, and cry my lord as lowed,
As ere a listed gown-man of them all.
I never plead before the honoured bench,
But bench right-worshipful of peaceful justices
And country-gentlemen, and yet I've found
Good gettings by the mass, besides odd cheats,
Will Smallshanks lands and many garboils more,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Have you drawn't at length, have you dashed it out,
According to your name.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Is the demurror drawn twixt snip and woodcock,
And what do you say to peacock's pitiful bill,

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: I have drawn his answer negative to all.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Negative to all. The plaintive says,
That William goose, was son to Thomas goose,
And will 'a swear the general bill is false.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then he forswears his father, 'tis well,
Some of our clients will go prig to hell
Before ourselves; has a paid all his fees.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: A lest them all with me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Then truss my points,
And how thinkst thou of law?

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: Most reverently,
Law is the world's great light, a second sun,
To this terrestrial globe, by which all things
Have life and being, and without which
Confusion and disorder soon would seize
The general state of men, wars, outrages,
The ulcerous deeds of peace, it curbs and cures,
It is the kingdom's eye, by which she sees
The acts and thoughts of men.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The kingdom's eye,
I tell thee fool, it is the kingdom's nose,
by which she smells out all these rich transgressors,
Nor is't of flesh but merely made of wax,
And 'tis, within the power of us lawyers,
To wrest this nose of wax which way we please.
Or it may be as thou sayest an eye indeed.
But if it be 'tis sure a woman's eyeKnock within.
That's ever rolling.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Go see who 'tis,
Stay, my chair, and gown, and then go see who knocks.
Thus must I seem a lawyer which am indeed,
But merely dregs and offscum of the law,En. Bou. Dash. and Consta.
I tricesimo primo alberti magni
'Tis very clear.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: The place is very pregnant, master Boucher;
Most hearty welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You ply this gear,
You are no truant in the law, I see.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some hundred books in folio I have
Turned over to better my own knowledge,
But that is nothing for a student,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Or a stationer they turn them over too,
But not as you do gentle master throat,
And what? the law speaks profit does it not?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some bad angels haunt us now and then,
But what brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: I am in law.
But let that go, and tell me how you do,
How does will Smallshanks and his lovely bride,

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks
sp.l: Introth you make me blush, I should have asked,
His health of you, but 'tis not yet too late.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Nay good sir throat forbear your quillets now,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: By heaven I deal most plain, I saw him not,
Since last I took his mortgage.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Sir be not nice,
(Yet I must needs herein commend your love)
To let me see him; for know I know him wed,
And that a stole away Somerfield's heir,
Therefore suspect me not I am his friend,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: How wed to rich Somerfield's only heir,
Is old Somerfield dead?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: By heaven I know it nor.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Then am I grieved.
I spoke so much (But that I know you love him.
And is reserved for gross and hungry stomachs.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: Come in faith you do:
And let me tell you that's but ceremony,
For though the pie be broken up before,
Yet says the proverb, the deeper is the sweeter.
I should entreat your secrecy sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: Nay good sir stay, if ought you can disclose
Of master Smallshanks good, let me partake,
And make me glad in knowing his good hap.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: You much endear him sir, and from your love,
I dare presume you make yourself a fortune
If his fair hopes proceed.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Or be my tongue torn out.

sp.speaker: Bouch.
sp.l: Measure for a lawyer, but to the point
Has stole Somerfield's heir hither 'a brings her
As to a man on whom a may rely
His life and fortunes: you hath a named
Already for the steward of his lands,
To keep his courts, and to collect his rent,
To let out leases and to raise his fines,
Nothing that may, or love, or profit bring,
But you are named the man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I am his slave
And bound unto his noble courtesy -
Even with my life, I ever said a would thrive,
And I protest I kept his forfeit mortgage,
To let him know what 'tis to live in want.

sp.speaker: Bour.
sp.p: I think no less, one word more in private.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Good master dash shall I put you now a case.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then thus it is,
Suppose I am a page, he is my master,
My master goes to bed and cannot tell
What money's in his hose, I ere next day
Have filched out some, what action lies for this.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.l: An action boy, called firking the posteriors,
With us your action seldom comes in question:
For that 'tis known that most of your gallants
Are seldom so well stored, that they forget
What money's in their hose, but if they have,
there is no other help then swear the page
And put him to his oath.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: Then fecks-law,
Dost think that he has conscience to steal,
Has not a conscience likewise to deny.
Then hang him up i'faith.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Commend me to them, come when they will,
My doors stand open and all within is theirs
And though ram stinks with cooks and ale,
Yet say there's many a worthy lawyers chamber,
Butts upon Ram-alley, I have still an open throat,
If ought I have which may procure his good,
Bid him command, ay, though it be my blood. Ex.

div.head: Actus secundi. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Oliver Smaleshanke, Thomas small shank.

sp.speaker: S. Oli.
sp.p: Is this the place you were appointed to meet him.

sp.speaker: Si. o.
sp.l: I find it true,
That wine, good news, and a young wholesome wench
Cheer up an old man's blood, I tell thee boy,
I am right hearty glad, to hear thy brother;
Hath got so great an heir; now were myself,
So well bestowed I should rejoice i'faith.

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks S.
sp.p: I hope you shall do well.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt.
A sirrah has a born the wench away,
My son i'faith, my very son i'faith,
When I was young and had an able back,
And wore the bristle on my upper lip,
In good decorum I had as good conveyance,
And could have fred, and ferked y'away a wench,
As soon as ear a man alive ; tut boy,
I had my winks, my becks treads on the toe,
Wrings by the fingers, smiles and other quirks,
No courtier like me, your courtiers all are fools,
To that which I could do, I could have done it boy.
Even to a hare, and that some ladies know,

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks S.
sp.l: Sir I am glad this match may reconcile,
Your love unto my brother.

sp.speaker: Si. o.
sp.l: 'Tis more than so.
I'll seem offended still though I am glad,
sp.stage: Enter Willian smals-shanke Francis, beard booted.
sp.l: Has got rich Somerfield's heir.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Come wench of gold,
For thou shalt get me gold, besides odd ends
Of silver: we'll purchase house and land,
By thy bare gettings, wench, by thy bare gettings,
How sayest lieutenant-beard, does she not look
Like a wench newly stole from a window?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Exceeding well she carries it by Jove;
And if she can forbear her rampant trick,
And but hold close a while 'twill take by Mars.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How now you slave? my rampant tricks you rogue,
Nay fear not me my only fear is still,
Thy filthy face betrays us, for all men know,
Thy nose stands compass like a bow,
Which is three quarters drawn, thy head.
Which is with greasy hair o'erspread,
And being uncurled and black as coal,
Doth show some scullion in a hole
Begotten thee on a Gipsy, or
Thy mother was some collier's whore
My rampant tricks you rogue, thou'lt be descried
Before our plot be ended.

sp.speaker: W, s.
sp.l: What should descry him,
Unless it be his nose? and as for that;
Thou mayst protest a was thy father's butler,
And for thy love is likewise run away,
Nay sweet lieutenant now forbear to puff,
And let the bristles of thy beard grow downward,
Reverence my punk and pandarize a little,
There's many of thy rank that do profess it,
Yet hold it no disparagement.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I shall do,
What fits an honest man.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Why that's enough,
Foot my father and the goose my brother,
Back you two.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Retire sweet lieutenant,
And come not on, till I shall wave you on.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: It shall be so, I'll cheat him that's flat.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: You are well met, know ye me good sir,
Belike you think I have no eyes, no ears,
No nose to smell, and wind out all your tricks,
You've stole sir Somerfield's heir, nay we can find,
Your wildest paths, your turnings and returns,
Your traces, squats, the insets, forms and holes,
You young men use, if once cursagest wits
Be set a hunting, are you now crept forth,
Have you hid your head within a suburb hole
All this while, and are you now crept forth?

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Who told you so did lie,
Foot, a gentleman cannot leave the city
And keep the suburbs to take a little physic,
But straight some slave will say he hides his head:
I hide my head within a suburb hole,
I could have holes at court to hide my head,
Were I but so disposed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Thou varlet knave,
T'hast stolen away sir John Somerfield's heir,
But never look for countenance from me,
Carry her whether thou wilt.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Father, father,
'Sheart will you undo your posterity.
Will you sir undo your posterity?
I can but kill my brother then hang myself,
And where is then your house, make me not despair,
Foot now I have got a wench, worth by the year
Two thousand pound and onwards, to cross my hopes:
Would ere a clown in Christendom do't but you.

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks S.
sp.l: Good father, let him leave this thundering,
And give him grace.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Why la, my brother knows
Reason, and what an honest man should do.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I'll give her somewhat, though I love not thee.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: My father right, I knew you could not hold
Out long with a woman, but give something
Worthy your gift and her acceptance father,
This chain were excellent by this good-light,
She shall give you as good if once her lands
Come to my fingering.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Peace knave, what's she your wife?

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: A ruffian sir,
By heaven, as tall a man as ere drew sword,
Not being counted of the damned crew,
'A was her father's butler, his name is beard,
Of with your mask, now shall you find me true,
And that I am a son unto a knight,
This is my father.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I am indeed fair maid,
My style is knight: come let me kiss your lips.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: That kiss shall cost your chain.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: It smacks i'faith,
I must commend your choice.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir I have given
A longer venture then true modesty
Will well allow, or your more graver wit
Commend.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: I dare be sworn she has.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Not so,
The foolish knave has been accounted wild,
And so have I, but I am now come home,
And so will he.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: I by this light will I.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Nay sigh not.
For you shall find him loving and me thankful.
And were it not a scandal to my honour,
To be consenting to my son's attempt,
You should unto my house, meanwhile take this,
As pledge and token of my after love:
How long since died your father.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Some six weeks since.
We cannot stay to talk, for slaves pursue,
I have a house shall lodge us till the priest
May make us sure.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Well sirrah, love this woman,
And when you are man and wife bring her to me,
She shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: I must be gone, I must a-wooing too.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: Jove and Priapus speed you, you'll return.

div.stage: Exit sir Oliver and Thom: Small-shank.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Why this came cleanly off.
Give me the chain, you little cockatrice,
Why this was luck, foot four hundred crowns
Got at a clap, hold still your own you whore,
and we shall thrive.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: Ay, when will your nose and beard perform as much.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am glad he is gone, a put me to the blush
When a did ask me of rich Somerfield's death.

sp.speaker: W s.
sp.l: And took not I my cue: wast not good,
Did I not bring you off, you arrant drab,
Without a counterbuff? look who comes here,
And three merry men, and three merry men,
And three merry men be we a.

div.stage: Enter Boutcher and Constantia.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Still in this vain, I have done you service,
The lawyer's house will give you entertainment,
Bountiful and free.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks s
sp.l: O nay second self,
Come let me buss thy beard, we are all made,
Why are so melancholy, dost want money?
Look here's gold, and as we pass along,
I'll tell thee how I got it, not a word
But that she's Somerfield's heir, my brother
Swallows it with more ease, than a Dutchman
Does flapdragons: 'a comes, now to my lawyers:
Kiss my wife, good brother; she is a wench
Was born to make us all.

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks S.
sp.l: I hope no less,
You're welcome sister into these our parts,
As I may say.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Come now to Ram-alley. There shalt thou lie,
Till I provide a priest.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: O villainy!
I think 'a will gull his whole generation,
I must make one, since 'tis so well begun,
I'll not forsake him, till his hopes be won. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter throat, and two citizens.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We are, so please your worship.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I am glad, keep your money, for law
Is like a butler's box: while you two strive,
That picks up all your money, you are friends,

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We are so please you, both perfect friends.

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks
sp.l: Why so,
Now to the next taphouse, there drink down this,
And by the operation of the third pot.
Quarrel again, and come to me for law:
Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: The gods concern your wisdom. E. Ci

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why so, these are tricks of the long fifteens,
To give counsel, and to take fees on both sides,
To make 'em friends, and then to laugh at them.
Why this thrives well, this is a common trick:
When men have spent a deal of money in law,
Than lawyers make them friends: I have a trick
To go beyond all these, if Small-shank come
And bring rich Somerfield's heir, I say no more,
But 'tis within this sconce to go beyond them.

div.stage: Enter Dash.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: Here are gentlemen in haste would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: I cannot know them sir
They are so wrapped in cloaks.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.p: Yes sir, but she's masked, and in her riding suit.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Go, make haste, bring them up with reverence,
O are they i'faith, has brought the wealthy heir:
These stools and cushions stand not handsomely.

div.stage: Enter William Smallshank, Boutcher. Thomas Smallshank, Francis, and beard.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: Welcome love, kiss this gentlewoman, throat.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Can you blame her since she has rid so hard?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: A fire in the great chamber, quickly.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: I that's well said, we are almost weary,
But master throat, if any come to inquire
For me, my brother, or this gentlewoman,
We are not here, nor have you heard of us.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Not a word sir, here you are as safe
As in your father's house,

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Thou'rt not merry love, good master throat
Bid this gentlewoman welcome: she is one
Of whom you may receive some courtesy
In time.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: She is most hearty welcome,
Wilt please you walk into another room ▪
where is both bed and fire,

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: Ay, ay, that that
Good brother lead her in, master throat and I
Will follow instantly, now master throatExit.
It rests within your power to pleasure me,
Know that this same is sir John Somerfield's heir,
Now if she chance to question what I am,
Say son unto a lord, I pray thee tell her
I have a world of land, and stand in hope
To be created baron, for I protest
I was constrained to swear it forty times
And yet she'll scarce believe me.

sp.speaker: Thro.
sp.l: Pauca sapienti,
Let me alone to set you out in length
And breadth:

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: I prithee do't effectually:
Shalt have a quarter share by this good light,
In all she has, I prithee forget not
To tell her the Smallshanks have been dancers,
Tilters, and very ancient courtiers,
And in request at court since sir John Shorthose
With his long silk stockings was beheaded,
Wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: Excellent, I'll but shift my boots, and then
Go seek a priest, this night I will be sure,
If we be sure, it cannot be undone,
Can it master throat?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O sir not possible:
You have many presidents and book cases for't,
Be you but sure and then let me alone.
Vivat rex, currat lex and I'll defend you.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.p: Nay then hang care, come let's in.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: A ha,
Have you stole her, fallere fallentem non est fraus. Exit. W. s,
It shall go hard but I will strip you boy.
You stole the wench, but I must her enjoy.Exit
Come Adriana, tell me what thou think'st,
I am tickled with conceit of marriage,
And whom think'st thou (For me) the fittest husband
What sayest thou to young Bouchor.

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: A pretty fellow
But that his back is weak,

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: What dost thou say
To throat the lawyer?

sp.speaker: Adri.
sp.l: I like that well,
were the rogue a lawyer, but he is none,
He never was of any Inn-of-court;
But inn of chancery, where a was known,
But only for a swaggering whiffler,
To keep out rogues, and prentices, I saw him,
When a was stocked for stealing the cook's fees.
A lawyer I could like, for 'tis a thing,
Used by you citizens wives, your husband's dead;
To get french-hoods you straight must lawyers wed,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What sayest thou then to nimble sir Oliv. Small-shank

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Faith he must hit the hair: a fellow fit,
To make a pretty cuckold: take an old man,
'Tis now the newest fashion, better be
An old man's darling, than a young man's warling,
Take me the old brisk knight, the fool is rich,
And will be strong enough to father children,
Though, not to get them.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: 'Tis true he is the man,
Yet will I bear some dozen more in hand,
And make them all my gulls.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Mistress stand aside.
Young Boutcher comes let me alone to touch him.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: The widow sir is not to be spoke to,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Not speak to, I must speak with her.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Must you!
Come you with authority, or do you come
To sue her with a warrant that you must speak with her.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: O you would entreat it,
May not I serve your turn, may not I unfold,
Your secrets to my mistress, love is your suit,

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: And why did you fall off
When you perceived my mistress was so cunning,
D'ye think she is still the same.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Why so,
I took you for a novice; and I must think,
You know not yet the innards of a woman,
Do you not know that women are like fish,
Which must be struck when they are prone to bite,
Or all your labours lost, but sir walk here.
And I'll inform my mistress your desires.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: By Jove
I never saw one go about his business
More untowardly: why sir, do not you know
That he which would be inward with the mistress,
Must make a way first through the waiting maid?
If you'll know the widow's affections
Feel first the waiting gentlewoman; do it master,
Some half a dozen kisses were not lost
Upon this gentlewoman, for you must know
These waiting-maids are to their mistresses
Like porches unto doors, you pass the one
Before you can have entrance at the other:
Or like your mustered to your piece of brawn,
If you'll have one taste well you must not scorn
To be dipping in the other, I tell you master
'Tis not a few men's tales which they prefer
Unto their mistress, in compass of a year -
Be ruled by me, untruss yourself to her,
Out with all your lovesick thoughts to her,
Kiss her and give her an angel to buy pins,
And this shall sooner win her mistress love,
Than all your protestations, scythes and tears.
Here they come; to her boldly master
Do, but dally not, that's the widow's phrase,

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Most worthy fair such is the power of love
That now I come t'accept your proffered grace,
And with submissive thoughts t'entreat a pardon
For my so gross neglect.

sp.speaker: Taff.
sp.l: There's no offence,
My mind is changed.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: I told you as much before.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: With a heigh pass with a repass.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Dearest of women,
The constant virtue of your nobler mind
Speaks in your looks: nor can you entertain
Both love and hate at once.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Stand thou propitious, endear me to thy love

div.stage: Boutcher gives Adriana his purse secretly.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Dear mistress turn to this gentleman, I protest,
I have some feeling of his constant love,
Cast him not away, try his love.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Why sir,
With what audacious front can you entreat
To enjoy my love, which yet not two hours since,
You scornfully refused.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: My fate compelled me, but now farewell fond fear,
My soul, my life, my lands, and reputation,
I'll hazard all, and prize them all beneath thee.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: Which I shall put to trial, lend me thy ear.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A pretty knave, i'faith come home tonight ,
Shalt have a posset and candied eringoes,
A bed if need be to, I love a life,
To play with such baboons as thou.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Indeed,
But dost think the widow will have my master.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: I'll tell thee then, wilt come.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Make him subscribe it, and then I vow,
By sacred Vesta's ever hallowed fire,
To take thee to my bed.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: He's worthy love, whose virtues most excel.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Remember, what is't a match betwixt you mistress?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: I have set the fool in hope, has undertook
To rid me of that fleshy captain face,
Which swears in taverns, and all ordinaries,
I am his lawful wife: he shall allay,
The fury of the captain, and I secure,
Will laugh at the disgrace they both endure. Ex:

div.stage: Enter throat and Francis.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Open your case, and I shall soon resolve you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: But will you do it truly.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This gentleman whom I so much affect,
I scarcely yet do know, so blind is love,
In things which most concerns it, as you're honest
Tell me his birth, his state, and farthest hopes.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: He is my friend, and I will speak him truly,
He is by birth, son to a foolish knight,
his present state I think will be the prison,
And farthest hope to be bailed out again,
By sale of all your land.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O me accursed,
Has 'a no credit, lands and manors.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: That lands he has lies in a fair Church-yard,
And for his manners, they are so rude and vild,
That scarce an honest man will keep him company.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I am abused, cozened, and deceived.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why that's his occupation, he will cheat
In a cloak lined with velvet, 'a will prate
Faster than five barbers and a tailor,
Lie faster than ten city occupiers,
Or cunning tradesmen: goes a trust
In every tavern where has spent a faggot,
Swears love to every whore, squires bawds,
And takes up houses for them as their husband.
'A is a man I love, and have done much
To bring him to preferment.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is there no trust,
No honesty in men.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Faith some there is,
And 'tis all in the hands of us lawyers
And women, and those women which have it,
Keep their honesty so close, that not one
Amongst a hundred is perceived to have it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Good sir, may I not by law forsake him
And wed another, though my word be past
To be his wife.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: O questionless you may,
You have many presidents and bookcases for't,
Nay, though you were married by a bookcase,
Of milesimo sexantesimo, etc.
You may forsake your husband, and wed another,
Provided that some fault be in the husband,
As none of them are clear.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I am resolved,
I will not wed him, though I beg my bread.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: All that I have is yours, and were I worthy
To be your husband.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you sir,
I will rather wed a most perfidious redshank,
A noted Jew, or some mechanic slave,
Then let him joy my sheets.

div.stage: Enter W Smal. Boutcher, T. Smal. beard.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Now my virago, 'tis done, all's cocksure,
I have a priest will mumble up a marriage,
Without bell, book, or candle, nimble slave,
A honest Welshman that was a tailor,
But now is made a curate.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: What all amort? what's the matter? do you here?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: What's the reason of this melancholy?

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Hold him to it wench,
And it 'twill hit by heaven: why art so sad?
Foot wench we will be married tonight ,
We'll sup at th'mitre, and from thence
My brother and we three will to the Savoy,
Which done, I tell thee girl, we'll hand o'er head,
Go to't pell-mell for a maidenhead,
Come you're lusty, you wenches are like bells,
You give no music, till you feel the clapper,
Come throat a torch, we must be gone.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This fellow has no land; and which is worse,
He has no credit.

sp.speaker: Bear.
sp.l: How are we outstripped,
Blown up by wit of man: let us be gone
Home again, home again, our market now is done.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: That were too great a scandal.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Most true,
Better to wed another then to return
With scandal and defame ▪ wed me a man
Whose wealth may reconcile your mother's love,
And make the action lawful.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: But where's the man?
I like your council, could you show the man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Myself am he, might I but dare aspire
Unto so high a fortune.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Mistress, take the man,
Shall we be baffled with fair promises,
Or shall we trudge, like beggars back again,
No, take this wise and virtuous man,
Who should a lose his legs, his arms, his ears,
His nose, and all his other members,
year if his tongue be left 'twill get his living,
Take me this man.

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, this night he means to wed me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: If not by law, we will with power prevent it,
So you but give consent.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I'll muster up my friends, and thus I cast it,
Whilst they are busy, you and I will hence
Directly to a chapel, where a priest
Shall knit the nuptial knot ere they pursue us.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: O rare invention, I'll act my part,
'A owes me thirteen pound, I say no more,
But there be catchpoles: speakest a match.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Get your sword
And me my buckler, nay you shall know
We are tam marti quam mercurio,
Bring my cloak, you shall thither, I'll for friends,
Worship and wealth the lawyer's state attends.
Dash, we must bear some brain, to saint John's street,
Go run, fly: and afar off inquire,
If that the lady Somerfield be there,
If there, know what news, and meet me straight
At the Myter door in Fleetstreet, away,
"To get rich wives, men must not use delay.

div.head: Actus 3. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter sir Oliver Smallshank, justice Tutchim.

sp.speaker: Justice Tu.
sp.p: A hunting sir Oliver and dry-foot to,

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: We old men have our crotchets, our conundrums,
Our fegaries, quirks and quibibles,
As well as youth, justice Tutchim I go
To hunt no buck, but prick a lusty doe,
I go in truth a-wooing .

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Then ride with me,
I'll bring you to my sister Somerfield.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Justice not so: by her there hangs a tale.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: I likewise have a son,
A villainous boy, his father up and down,
What should I say, these velvet bearded boys,
will still be doing, say what we old men can,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p: And what of this sir Oliver, be plain,

sp.speaker: S. Oli.
sp.l: A nimble spirited knave, the villain boy,
Has one trick of his sire, has got the wench.
Stolen your rich sister's heir.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Has done the deed, has pierced the vessel's head,
And knows by this the vintage.

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: As I am by my council well informed,
This very day,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Tut it cannot be,
Some ten miles hence I saw the maid last night.

sp.speaker: S. Ol,
sp.l: Maids may be maids tonight and not tomorrow.
Women are free and sell their maidenheads,
As men sell cloth, by yard and handful,
But if you chance to see your sister widow,
Comfort her tears and say her daughters matched,
With one that has a knocker to his father,
An honest noble knight.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Stand close knight, close,
And mark this captain's humour, his name is puff,
A dreams as 'a walks, and thinks no woman
Sees him but is in love with him.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: 'Twere brave,
If some great lady, through a window spied me,
And straight should love me, say she should send,
5000 pound unto my lodging,
And crave my company: with that money,
I would make three several cloaks, and line them
With black, crimson, and tawny three piled velvet,
I would eat at chares ordinary, and dice
At Antony's: then would I keep my whore,
In beaten velvet and, have two slaves to tend her.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: What my case of justices,
What are you eavesdropping or do you think,
Your tawny coats with greasy facings here,
Shall carry it? Sir Oliver Smallshanks,
Know my name is puff, knight, thee have I sought,
To fright thee from thy wits.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: Nay good sir puff,
We have to many mad men already,

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: How? I tell thee justice Tuchim, not all
thy bailiffs, sergeants busy constables,
Defesants, warrants, or thy mittimuses,
Shall save his throat from cutting if he presume,
To woe the widow yclept Tafata,
She is my wife by oath. Therefore take heed,
Let me not catch thee in the widow's house,
If I do, I'll pick thy head upon my sword,
And piss in thy very visnomy, beware, beware.
Come there no more, a captain's word,
Flies not so fierce as doth his fatal sword,Exit Puffe.

sp.speaker: Si. o.
sp.l: How like you this, shall we endure this thunder,
Or go no further.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: We will on sir Oliver,
We will on, let me alone to touch 'im,
I wonder how my spirit did forbear,
To strike him on the face: had this been spoke,
Within my liberties, had died for it.

div.stage: Enter Cap. Puffe.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: If you come there,
Thy beard shall serve to stuff, those balls by which
I get me heat at tennis.

sp.speaker: I Tu.
sp.l: Is he gone. Exit Puffe.
I would a durst a stood to this awhile,
Well I shall catch him in a narrow room,
Where neither of us can flinch; if I do,
I'll make him dance a trenchmoor to my sword,
Come I'll along with you to the widow.
We will not be outbraved, take my word,
We'll not be wronged while I can draw a sword. Exit.

div.stage: Enter throat and other gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Let the Cotch stay at Show-lane end: be ready,
Let the boot stand open, and when she's in:
Hurry towards saint Gyles in the field,
As if the devil himself were wagoner,
Now for an arm of oak, and heart of steel,
To bear away the wench, to get a wife,
A gentlewoman, a maid, nay which is more,
An honest maid, and which is most of all,
A rich and honest maid: oh Jove Jove!
For a man to wed such a wife as this,
is to dwell in the very suburbs of heaven,

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sir she is rich
And a great heir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dangerous? Lord where be those gallant spirits,
The time has been when scarce an honest woman,
Much less a wench could pass an inn of court,
But some of the fry would have been doing
With her: I knew the day when shreds a tailor
Coming once late by an inn of chancery,
Was laid a long, and muffled in his cloak,
His wife took in, stitched up, turned out again,
And he persuaded all was but in jest,
Tut those brave boys are gone, these which are left,
Are wary lads, live poring on their books,
And give their linen to their laundresses,
By tail, they now can save their purses,
I knew when every gallant had his man.
But now a twelvepenny weekly laundress,
Will serve the turn to half a dozen of them,
Here comes my man, what news.

sp.speaker: Das.
sp.l: As you would wish.
The lady Somerfield is come to town,
Her horses yet are walking, and her men say,
Her only daughter, is conveyed away,
No man knows how: now to it mast,
You and your servant dash are made for ever
If you but stick to it now.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Now show yourselves at full, and not a man,
But shares a fortune with me if I speed.

div.stage: Enter William Smallshank Boutcher. Thomas Smallshank, Francis and Bear. with a torch.

sp.speaker: 1. Gentleman
sp.l: Tut fear not us be sure you run away,
And we'll perform the quarrel.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.p: Art sure he will be here

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Bear up the torch, and keep your way apace
Directly to the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks S.
sp.l: Have you a licence,
Look to that brother before you marry,
For fear the parson lose his benefice.

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Tut our curate craves no licence, 'a swears
His living came to him by a miracle,

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: Why 'a paid nothing fort,
'A swears that few be free from simony,
But only Welshmen, and those 'a says to,
Are but mountain priests ▪

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: But hang him fool he lies,
What's his reason?

sp.speaker: Wi. S.
sp.l: His reason is this,
That all their livings are so rude and bare,
That not a man, will venture his damnation
By giving money for them: a does protest,
There is but two pair, of hose, and shoes,
In all his parish.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Shall I be taught how to advance my torch,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: How an ass; die men like dogs.

sp.speaker: Thomas_smallshanks S.
sp.l: Hold brother hold, lieutenant.
Put up as you are men, your wife is gone.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: How, which way? this is some plot,

sp.speaker: 1. Gentleman
sp.l: So has the wench let us pursue a loof,
And see the event, this will prove good mirth,
When things unshaped shall have a perfect birth. Exit.

div.stage: Enter W. Smal-shancke Boucher, Thom. Smal. and beard, their swords drawn.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: 'Tis a thing unpossible, they should be gone
Thus far and we not see them.

sp.speaker: T.
sp.l: Upon my life.
They went in by the greyhound, and so struck,
Into Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Water at dock,
A fico for her dock, you'll not be ruled.
You'll still be obstinate, I'll pawn my fate,
She took a long show-lane, and so went home,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I home; how could she choose but go,
Seeing so many naked tools at once,
Drawn in the street?

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Come we will find her, or we'll fire the suburbs,
Put up your tools, let's first along show-lane,
Then straight up Holborn, if we find her not;
we'll thence direct to throats, if she be lost
I am undone and all your hopes are crossed. Exit.

div.stage: Enter sir Oliver Smaleshankes, justice Tutchim, mistress Tafata, Adriana.

sp.speaker: Justice Tu.
sp.l: Sir Oliver,
Will you shame yourself, ha? You must be short,
Why what a word was that to tell a widow?

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: I meant I must be brief.

sp.speaker: Justice tut.
sp.l: Why say so then,
Yet that's almost as ill; go to, speak on.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: Widow I must be brief, what old men do,
They must do quickly.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Then good sir do it,
Widows are seldom slow to put men to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: And old men know their q's, my love you know,
Has been protested long, and now I come
To make my latest tender, an old grown oak
Can keep you from the rain, and stands as fair
And portly as the best .

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Yet search him well,
And we shall find no pith or hearty timber
To underlay a building.

sp.speaker: Justice Tu.
sp.l: I would that oak
Had been a fire: forward good sir Oliver,
Your oak is naught: stick not too much to that.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: If you can like, you shall be ladified,
Live at the court, and soon be got with child,
What do you think we old men can do nothing?

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.l: You shall have jewels,
A baboon, parrot, and an Iceland dog,
And I myself to bear you company.
Your jointure is five hundred pound by year,
Besides your plate, your chains and household stuff,
When envious fate shall change this mortal life.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: But shall I not be overcloyed with love?
Will you nor be too busy shall I keep
My chamber by the month, if I be pleased
To take physic, to send for visitants,
To have my maid read Amadis de Gaul,
Or Donzel deal Phoebo to me? shall I have
A caroche of the last edition,
The coachman's seat a good way from the coach,
that if some other ladies and myself
Chance to talk bawdy, he may not overhear us.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Shall we have two chambers?
And will you not presume unto my bed,
Till I shall call you by my waiting maid.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: And when I send her,
Will you not entice her to your lust,
Nor tumble her before you come to me.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Nay let him do his worst, make your match sure,
And fear not me, I never yet did fear
Any thing my master could do to me. Knock.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: What noise is that, go see Adriana,
And bring me word: I am so haunted
With a swaggering captain, that swears God bless us
Like a very termagant, a rascal knave,Enter Adr.
That says he will kill all men which seeks to wed me.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: O mistress! Captain puff half drunk, is now
Coming up stairs.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: O God have you no room
Beyond this chamber, has sworn to kill me,
And piss in my very visnomy,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: What are you afraid sir Oliver?

sp.speaker: S. Ol
sp.l: Not afraid,
But of all men I love not to meddle with a drunkard:
Have you any Rome backwards.

sp.speaker: Justice Tu.
sp.l: Is there ne'er a trunk or cupboard for him,
Is there ne'er a hole backwards to hide him in.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Creep under my mistress farthingale knight,
That's the best and safest place in the chamber.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p: I there, there, that he will never mistrust.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Enter knight, keep close, gather yourself
Round like a hedgehog stir not whate'er you near,
See or smell knight, God bless us, here 'a comes. Ent. C. Puff.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir get you gone.
Leave my house, or I will have you conjured
With such a spell, you never yet have heard of,
Have you no other place to vent your froth,
But in my house, is this the fittest place,
Your captainship can find to puff in: ha!

sp.speaker: Captain Pu.
sp.l: How, am I not thy spouse, didst thou not say,
These arms should clip thy naked body fast,
Betwixt two linen sheets, and be sole lord
Of all thy pewter work, thy word is past,
And know that man is powder, dust, and earth,
That shall once dare to think thee for his wife.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.p: How now you slave, one call the constable.

sp.speaker: C. Puf.
sp.l: No constable with all his holberteeres,
Dare once advance his head, or peep up stairs,
If I cry but keep down: have I not lived,
And marched on the sieged walls,
In thunder, lightning, rain, and snow,
And eke in shot of powdered balls,
Whose costly marks are yet to show?

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Captain face, for my last husband's sake,
With whom you were familiarly acquainted,
I am content to wink at these rude tricks,
But hence, trouble me no more, if you do,
I shall lay you fast, where you shall see
No sun or moon.

sp.speaker: C, Puf.
sp.l: Nor yet the Northern pole,
A fico for the sun and moon, let me live in a hole,
So these two stars may shine.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir, get you gone,
You swaggering, cheating, Turnbull-street rogue,
Or I will hale you to the common-jail,
Where lice shall eat you.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Go to, I shall spurn
And slash your petticoat.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Run to the counter,
Fetch me a red-bearded Sargeant, I'll make
You captain think the devil of hell is come
To fetch you, if he once fasten on you.

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Damn thee and thy sergeants, thou mercer's punk.
Thus will I kick thee and thy farthingales.

sp.speaker: C Pu.
sp.l: What do you cast your whelps.
What have I found you sir? have not I placed
My sakers, culverings, demi-culverings,
My cannons, demi-cannons, basilisks,
Upon her breach, and do I not stand,
Ready with my pike to make my entry,
And are you come to man her?

sp.speaker: C. Pu.
sp.l: Are not her bulwarks parapets, trenches,
Scarves, counter-scarves, fortifications,
Curtains, shadows, mines, countermines,
Rampires, forts, ditches, works, waterworks,
And is not her half-moon mine, and do you bring
A rescue goodman knight

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Call up my men,Enter 2. or 3. with clubs.
Where be these knaves, have they no ears or hearts,
Beat hence this rascal, some other fetch a warrant,
I'll teach him know himself.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: 'Tis not your beard shall carry it, down with the rogue.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: A sirrah,Ex: Face
I knew my hands no longer could forbear him,
Why did you not strike the knave, sir Oliver?

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.p: But then it was too late.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: What would you have me do when I was down,
And he stood thundering with his weapon drawn,
Ready to cut my throat.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: The rogue is gone,
And here's one from the lady Somerfield,
To entreat you come with all the speed you can,
To saint John's street.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Gentlemen
I am sorry you should be thus disturbed
Within my house, but now all fear is past,
You are most welcome: supper ended,
I'll give a gracious answer to your suit,
Meanwhile let naught dismay, or keep you mute. Ex.

div.stage: Enter throat, Francis, and Dash.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Pay the coachman dash, pay him well,
And thank him for his speed. Now vivat rex,
The knot is knit, which not the law itself,
With all his Hydra heads and strongest nerves,
Is able to disjoin: now let him hang,
Fret out his guts, and swear the stars from heaven,
A never shall enjoy you, you shall be rich.
Your lady mother this day came to town
In your pursuit: we will but shift some rags,
And straight go take her blessing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That must not be,
furnish me with jewels, and then myself,
Attended by you man and honest beard,
Will thither first, and with my lady mother
Crave a peace for you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I like that well,
Her anger somewhat calmed, I brisk and fine,
Some half hour after will present myself
As son in law unto her, which she must needs
Accept with gracious looks.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I when she knows
Before by me, from what an eminent plague
Your wisdom has preserved me.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ay, that, that,
That will strike it dead: but here comes beard.

div.stage: Enter beard.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.p: What are you sure, tide fast by heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I now do call her wife, she now is mine,
Sealed and delivered by an honest priest,
At saint Giles in the field.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: O hard at hand,
And almost mad with loss of his fair bride ▪
Let not my lovely mistress be seen,
And see if you can draw him to compound
For all his title to her, I have sergeants
Ready to do the feat, when time shall serve.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Stand you aside dear love nay I will firk
My silly novice, as he was never firked
Since midwives bound his noddle: here they come.

div.stage: Enter W. Smallsh. Th. Smalsh. and Boucher.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: O master throat, unless you speak good news,
My hopes are crossed, and I undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I never thought you'd come to other end,
Your courses have been always so profane,
Extravagant and base.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Nay good sir hear?
Did not my love return? came she not hither,
For Jove's love speak.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Sir will you get you gone,
And seek your love elsewhere; for know my house
Is not to entertain such customers
As you and your comrades.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Is the man mad,
Or drunk, why master throat know you to whom
You talk so saucily?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Why unto you,
and to your brother Small-shanks, will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: Nay good sir hold us not in this suspense,
Answer directly, came not the virgin hither.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Will you be gone directly, are you mad?
Come you to seek a virgin in Ram-alley
So near an inn of court, and amongst cooks,
Ale-men and laundresses, why are you fools?

sp.speaker: W Sm.
sp.l: Sir leave this firk of law, or by this light
I'll give your throat a slit, came she not hither?
Answer to that point.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: What, have you lost her?
Come do not gull your friends.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: By heaven she's gone
Unless she be returned since we last left you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Nay then I cry you mercy, she came not hither
As'am an honest man: is't possible
A maid so lovely, fair, so well demeaned,
Should be taken from you? what from you three?
So young, so brave and valiant gentlemen?
Sure it cannot be.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.p: To our perpetual shames 'tis now too true.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Is she not left behind you in the tavern ▪
Are you sure you brought her out? were you not drunk
And so forgotten her?

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: A pox on all such luck,
I will find her, or by this good light
I'll fire all the city, come let's go,
Whoever has her shall not long enjoy her,
I'll prove a contract, let's walk the round,
I'll have her if she keep above the ground. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, 'a makes me sport. ifaith
The gull is mad, stark mad, dash draw the bond
And a release of all his interest
In this my loved wife,

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I be sure of that,
For I have certain goblins in buff jerkinsEnter with the sergeants.
Lie in ambuscado for him.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: I'll give you bail
Hang off honest catchpoles

sp.speaker: M. Thr.
sp.l: Good, wise,
Learned, and honest master throat, now, now,
Now or never help me ..

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks Sm.
sp.l: Here are two retainers, hangers on sir,
which will consume more than ten liveries,
If by your means they be not straight shook off:
I am arrested.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: But thirteen pound, due to beard the butler,
Do but bail me, and I will save you harmless.

sp.speaker: Thr,
sp.l: Why here's the end of riot, I know the law,
If you be bailed by me, the debt is mine,
Which I will undertake.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: La there; rogues,
Foot I know he would not let me want
For thirteen pounds.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Provided, you seal a release,
Of all your claim to mistress Somerfield.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Sergeants do your kind, hale me to the hole,
Seal a release, sergeants come, to prison,
Seal a release for mistress Somerfield,
First I will stink in jail, be eat with lice,
Endure an object worse than the devil himself,
And that's ten sergeants peeping through the grates
Upon my lousy linen, come to jail,
Foot a release.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, impudent man.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: My wife, foot my wife, let me go sergeants.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O thou perfidious man dar'st thou presume
To call her wife, whom thou so much hast wronged,
What conquest hast thou got, to wrong a maid,
A silly harmless maid? what glory is't
That thou hast thus deceived a simple virgin,
And brought her from her friends? what honour wast
For thee to make the butler lose his office
And run away with thee. Your tricks are known,
Didst thou not swear thou shouldst be baronized?
And hadst both lands and fortunes? both which thou wantest.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Foot that's not my fault, I would have lands
If I could get 'em.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I know your trick:,
And know I now am wife unto this man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: I thank her sir, she has now vouchsafed
To cast herself on me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Therefore subscribe,
Take somewhat of him for a full release,
and pray to God to make you an honest man,
If not, I do protest by earth and heaven,
Although I starve, thou never shalt enjoy me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Her vow is past, nor will she break her word ▪
Look to it mitcher.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks s
sp.l: Foot shall I give two thousand pound a year
For nothing.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.l: Brother come, be ruled by me,
Better to take a little then lose all.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: You see she's resolute, y'had best compound.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: I'll first be damned ere I will lose my right,
Unless 'a give me up my forfeit mortgage,
And bail me of this action.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir you may choose,
What's the mortgage worth?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do it, do it,
Come you shall do it, we will be rid of him
At any rate.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Dash, go fetch his mortgage,
See that your friends be bound, you shall not claim
Title, right, possession in part or whole,
In time to come, in this my loved wife:
I will restore the mortgage, pay this debt,
And set you free.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.l: We will,
Come draw the bonds, and we will soon subscribe them.

div.stage: Enter Dash.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: They're ready drawn; here's his release,
Sergeants let him go.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Was ever man thus cheated of a wife:
Is this my mortgage.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Well I will subscribe, God give you joy,
Although I have but little cause to wish it,
My heart will scarce consent unto my hand,
'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You give this as your deeds.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: You are, sergeants I discharge you,
There's your fees.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Not so, I must have money.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Foutrè, words are wind,
I say I must have money.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Three pounds in hand, and all the rest tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: There's your sum, now officers begone,
each take his way, I must to saint John's street,
And see my lady-mother: she's now in town,
And we to her shall straight present our duties.

sp.speaker: T.s.
sp.p: O Jove shall we lose the wench thus.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Even thus
Throat farewell, since 'tis thy luck to have her,
I still shall pray, you long may live together:
Now each to his affairs.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.l: Good night to all,Ex:
Dear wife step in, beard and dash come hither:
Here take this money: go borrow jewels
Of the next goldsmith: beard take thou these books,
Go both to the brokers in Fetter lane,
Lay them in pawn for a velvet jerkin
And a double ruff, tell him 'a shall have
As much for loan tonight , as I do give
Usually for a whole circuit, which done
You two shall man her to her mothers: go,Ex.
My fate looks big; methinks I see already,
Nineteen gold chains, seventeen great beards, and ten
Reverent bald heads, proclaim my way before me,
My coach shall now go prancing through Cheapside,
And not be forced to hurry through the streets,
For fear of sergeants: nor shall I need to try,
Whether my well-graft tumbling foot-cloth nag,
Be able to outrun a well-breathed catchpole ,
I now in pomp will ride, for 'tis most fit,
He should have state that riseth by his wit. Ex.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Sir Oliver, justice Tutchim, taffeta, Adriana.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Good meat the belly fills, good wine the brain,
Women please men, men pleasure them again,
Ka me, ka thee, one thing must rub another,
English love Scots, Welshmen love each other.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: You say very right sir Oliver, very right,
I have't in my noddle i'faith, that's all the fault
Old justices have, when they are at feasts,
They will bib hard, they will be fine: sunburnt
sufficient, foxed, or columbered now and than,
Now could I sit in my chair at home and nod
A drunkard to the stocks, by virtue of,
The last statute rarely.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Sir you are merry,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: Your supper sir was light.
But I hope you think you welcome.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: I do,
A light supper quoth you, pray God it be,
Pray god I carry it cleanly, I am sure it lies,
As heavy in my belly as moult lead,
Yet I'll go see my sister Somerfield,

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: I even so late,
Night is the mother of wit, as you may see,
By poets or rather constables
In their examinations at midnight,
We'll lie together without marrying,
Save the curate's fees, and the parish a labour,
'Tis a thriving course.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: That may not be,
For excommunications then will flee.

sp.speaker: I. Tu.
sp.l: That's true, they fly indeed like wildgeese,
In flocks, one in the breech of another.
But the best is a small matter stays them,
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Farewell good justice Tutchim,Exit.
Alas good gentleman his brains are erased,
But let that pass: speak widow is't a match,
Shall we clap it up.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Nay if't come to clapping,
Good night i'faith mistress look before you,
There's nothing more dangerous to maid or widow,
Then sudden clapings up; nothing has spoilt,
So many proper ladies as clappings up:
Your shuttlecock, striding from tables to ground,
Only to try the strength of the back,
Your riding a hunting, I though they fall,
With their heels upward, and lay as if
They were taking the height, of some high star
With a cross staff: no nor your iumlings
In horsslitters, coaches or caroches,
Have spoilt so many women as clappings up,

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.p: Why then we'll chop it up.

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: That's not allowed.
Unless you were son to a Welsh curate:
But faith sir knight I have a kind of itching,
To be a lady, that I can tell you woes,
And can persuade with better rhetoric,
Than oaths, wit, wealth, valour, lands, or person,
I have some debts at court, and marrying you,
I hope the courtier will not stick to pay me,

sp.speaker: Si. Ol.
sp.l: Never fear thy payment. This I will say,
For courtiers they'll be sure to pay each other,
Howe'er they deal with citizens.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Then here's my hand,
I am your wife condition we be joined,
Before to morrows sun.

sp.speaker: Si. o.
sp.l: Nay even tonight ,
So you be pleased with little warning widow,
We old men can be ready, and thou shalt see,
Before the time that chanticleer,
Shall call and tell the day is near,
When wenches lying on their backs,
Receive with joy their love-stolen smacks,
When maids awaked from their first sleep,
Deceived with dreams begin to weep,
And think if dreams, such pleasures know,
What sport the substance them would show,
When ladies 'gin white limbs to spread,
Her love but new stolen to her bed,
His cotton shows yet scarce put off,
And dares not laugh, speak, sneeze, or cough,
When precise dames begin to think,
Why their gross souring husbands stink,
What pleasure 'twere then to enjoy,
A nimble vicar, or a boy.
Before this time thou shalt behold,
Me quaffing out our bridal bowl.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Then belike before the morning sun
You will be coupled.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Well I will look you shall have a clean smock,
Provided that you pay the fee sir Oliver,
Since my mistress sir will be a lady,
I'll lose no fees due to the waiting maid.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.p: Why is there a fee belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: A knight and never heard of smock fees,
I would I had the monopoly of them,
So there were no impost set upon them:Enter W. Sm.

sp.speaker: S. Ol.
sp.l: Whom have we here what my mad-headed son
What makes he here so late? say I am gone,
And I the whilst will step behind the hangings.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.p: God bless thee parcel of man's flesh,

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Why parcel of man's flesh art not a woman?
But widow where's the old stinkard my father,
They say widow you dance altogether.
After his pipe.

sp.speaker: W.s.
sp.l: Thar't a fool,
I'll assure thee there's no music in it.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Better widow?
Blood dost think I have not learned my prick song,
What not the court pricksong? one up and another down,
Why I have't to a hare by this light.
I hope thou lovest him not.

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: How marry him, foot art mad widow,
Wilt marry an old crazed man,
With meager looks, with visage won,
With little legs and cryncled thighs,
With chap-fallen gums and deep sunk eyes,
Why a dog seized on ten days by death
Stinks nor so loathsome as his breath,
Nor can a city common jaques,
Which all men's breeches undertakes,
Yield fasting stomachs such a favour.
As doth his breath, and ugly favour.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: That's all one sir she means to be a lady,

sp.speaker: William-smallshanks
sp.l: Does she so, and thou must be her waiting woman.
Faith thou wilt make a fine dainty creature,
To sit at a chamber door and look fleas,
In thy lady's dog while she is showing,
Some slippery breeched courtier rare faces,
In a by window, foot widow,
Marry me a young and complete gallant,

sp.speaker: Taf.
sp.l: How a complete gallant? what? A fellow,
With a hat tuck't up behind, and what we use,
About our hips to keep our coats from dabbling,
He wears about his neck, a farthingale:
A standing collar to keep his neat band clean,
The whilst his shirt does stink, and is more foul,
Than an in of chancery table cloth,
His breeches must be pleated as if a had
Some thirty pockets, when one poor halfpenny purse,
Will carry all his treasure, his knees all points,
As if his legs and hams were tied together,
A fellow that has no inside, but prates
By rote, as players, and parrots use to do,
And to define a complete gallant right,
A mercer formed him, a tailor made him,
And a player gives him spright,

sp.speaker: Wi. Sm.
sp.l: Why so, in my conscience to be a countess,
